description: Social psychology foundations: how people think, feel, and act in social contexts—attitudes, influence, groups, identity, prejudice, relationships, and prosocial/antisocial behavior. Built for Marion to answer 'why people do that' questions with clean caveats and practical, non-clinical insights.

coreConcepts.name: Social Cognition
coreConcepts.oneLiner: We use mental shortcuts to interpret people and situations—fast, useful, and sometimes wrong.
keyPoints: Schemas guide attention and interpretation; they can create blind spots.
Heuristics reduce cognitive load but increase systematic biases.
Attributions: explaining behavior via person (disposition) vs situation.
commonMisconceptions: If I feel confident, I must be correct.
Behavior always reflects personality more than context.

coreConcepts.name: Fundamental Attribution Error
coreConcepts.oneLiner: We over-attribute others’ behavior to personality and underweight the situation.
keyPoints: Stronger for judging others than ourselves (actor–observer asymmetry).
Reduced when situational constraints are salient and specific.
Can be moderated by culture (some contexts weigh situation more).
commonMisconceptions: I’m objective about other people’s motives.
If someone did it, they wanted to.

coreConcepts.name: Self-Concept and Identity
coreConcepts.oneLiner: The self is both personal (traits) and social (group memberships) and shifts by context.
keyPoints: Self-schema influences goals, emotion, and attention.
Social identity: belonging to groups shapes beliefs and behavior.
Self-esteem can be buffered by group pride or threatened by exclusion.
commonMisconceptions: People have one stable self that never shifts.
Group identity is always irrational.

coreConcepts.name: Attitudes
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Attitudes are evaluations—shaped by beliefs, feelings, and past behavior—and they predict behavior best when specific and accessible.
keyPoints: ABC model: affect, behavior, cognition.
Attitude–behavior link strengthens with specificity and low social pressure.
Attitudes can be explicit (reported) or implicit (automatic associations).
commonMisconceptions: Attitudes always predict behavior.
Implicit measures are perfect lie detectors.

intentSignals: why did they change their mind

coreConcepts.name: Cognitive Dissonance
coreConcepts.oneLiner: When behavior and beliefs conflict, people reduce discomfort by changing beliefs, justifying behavior, or shifting attention.
keyPoints: Dissonance is stronger when people feel choice and responsibility.
Justification can be internal (belief change) or external (excuses).
Can lead to escalation of commitment: doubling down after costs.
commonMisconceptions: Only weak-minded people rationalize.
Dissonance always causes immediate belief change.

intentSignals: why won't they admit they're wrong

coreConcepts.name: Persuasion
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Persuasion works through message content and mental route: thoughtful processing vs shortcuts.
keyPoints: Dual-process: central/systematic vs peripheral/heuristic routes.
Credibility, liking, and social proof influence heuristic route.
Strong arguments + motivated audience strengthen durable change.
commonMisconceptions: Facts alone persuade everyone.
Charisma beats evidence in all contexts.

coreConcepts.name: Social Influence and Norms
coreConcepts.oneLiner: People conform to fit in (normative) and to be right (informational).
keyPoints: Normative influence: approval/avoid rejection.
Informational influence: uncertainty → adopt group as evidence.
Norms can be descriptive (what is done) or injunctive (what is approved).
commonMisconceptions: Conformity means lack of character.
If many people do it, it must be correct.

coreConcepts.name: Obedience and Authority
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Authority structures can amplify compliance—especially under ambiguity, diffusion of responsibility, and gradual escalation.
keyPoints: Situational framing and legitimacy cues increase obedience.
Foot-in-the-door: small commitments escalate to bigger ones.
Accountability and dissent reduce harmful compliance.
commonMisconceptions: Only bad people obey harmful orders.
Obedience is purely a personality trait.

coreConcepts.name: Group Processes and Roles
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Groups shape identity, behavior, and decision quality through norms, roles, and dynamics.
keyPoints: Roles are expectations; they can override personal preferences.
Group polarization: groups often shift to more extreme positions.
Groupthink risk rises with cohesion + poor dissent + high stakes.
commonMisconceptions: Groups average out biases (they often amplify them).
Strong leaders automatically improve decisions.

coreConcepts.name: Deindividuation
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Anonymity + arousal + group immersion can reduce self-monitoring and increase norm-following (good or bad).
keyPoints: Doesn’t always lead to antisocial behavior; it amplifies dominant norms.
Online contexts can increase disinhibition (with moderating factors).
Accountability cues reduce harmful effects.
commonMisconceptions: Anonymity always makes people cruel.
Deindividuation equals 'loss of self' in all cases.

intentSignals: why people act different in groups

coreConcepts.name: Prejudice and Discrimination
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Bias can be explicit or implicit, individual or structural; discrimination is behavior, prejudice is attitude.
keyPoints: Ingroup favoritism is common even without outgroup hatred.
Stereotypes can be activated automatically, but behavior is modifiable.
Contact under the right conditions can reduce prejudice.
commonMisconceptions: Implicit bias means someone is secretly hateful.
Prejudice is only an individual moral failure (structures matter too).

coreConcepts.name: Stereotype Threat
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Performance can drop when people fear confirming a negative stereotype about their group.
keyPoints: Triggered by identity salience and high-stakes evaluation.
Can be reduced by belonging cues, reframing, and supportive norms.
Not the sole explanation for group differences—context matters.
commonMisconceptions: It affects everyone equally in every test.
It explains all achievement gaps by itself.

coreConcepts.name: Aggression
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Aggression emerges from person × situation: provocation, norms, modeling, and self-control resources.
keyPoints: Frustration can increase aggression, especially with provocation cues.
Social learning: modeling and reinforcement shape aggression.
Self-control and sleep/stress load affect impulse control.
commonMisconceptions: Aggression is purely genetic.
Vent/‘catharsis’ reliably reduces aggression (often not).

coreConcepts.name: Prosocial Behavior
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Helping depends on attention, interpretation, responsibility, and perceived cost—plus empathy and norms.
keyPoints: Bystander effect: diffusion of responsibility when others are present.
Empathy increases helping, especially when costs are manageable.
Clear requests + role clarity increase intervention likelihood.
commonMisconceptions: If people don’t help, they’re immoral.
Helping is always altruistic (often mixed motives).

coreConcepts.name: Relationships and Attachment (Social Lens)
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Closeness grows from repeated positive exchanges, trust, and responsiveness; attachment patterns shape expectations under stress.
keyPoints: Interdependence: partners influence each other’s outcomes.
Responsiveness (seen, safe, valued) predicts satisfaction.
Conflict patterns matter more than conflict frequency.
commonMisconceptions: Healthy couples never fight.
Jealousy equals love.

coreConcepts.name: Culture and Social Behavior
coreConcepts.oneLiner: Culture tunes norms, self-construal (independent/interdependent), and what counts as 'appropriate' behavior.
keyPoints: Individualist vs collectivist tendencies shape attribution and persuasion.
Norm tightness/looseness affects conformity and deviance.
Avoid overgeneralizing: within-culture variation is large.
commonMisconceptions: Culture determines behavior rigidly.
One culture explanation fits everyone in that group.

frameworks.name: Attribution Matrix (Quick)
steps: Check for base rate neglect (how common is this generally?).
Choose a balanced explanation with uncertainty.

frameworks.name: Persuasion Planner
steps: Message: one clear claim + evidence + relevance.
Credibility: expertise + trust + alignment with values.
Friction: preempt objections, reduce cognitive load.

examples.title: Bystander Effect in Real Life
examples.scenario: A person collapses in a crowded area; people look around but no one calls for help immediately.
explanation: Ambiguity: people aren’t sure it’s an emergency.
Pluralistic ignorance: everyone watches everyone else for cues.
Diffusion of responsibility: 'someone else will act.'
whatHelps: Direct assignment: 'You in the blue jacket—call 911.'

examples.title: Dissonance and Doubling Down
examples.scenario: Someone invests heavily in a project and it starts failing; they invest even more.
explanation: Escalation of commitment reduces the pain of admitting loss.
Justification shifts from outcomes to identity ('I’m not a quitter').

examples.title: Norms Shape Behavior
examples.scenario: A new employee mirrors the team’s pace and communication style within a week.
explanation: Injunctive norms: learning what gets approval.

applicationRules.instruction: Explain social-psych concepts and practical interpersonal insights. Do not diagnose mental disorders or prescribe treatment.
If user content suggests violence/self-harm or coercion, prioritize safety framing and redirect to appropriate help; avoid tactical detail.
For persuasion requests, default to honest influence (clarity, relevance, empathy). Avoid manipulation, deception, or coercive tactics.
Use probabilistic language for motives ('likely', 'may') unless the user provides direct evidence; avoid mind-reading.
